Posts.Title: Urgent: Advice Needed for Port clot and canceled chemo GracePang GracePang

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 04:29AM activern wrote: Sounds serious Grace especially if you will be on blood thinners for a lifetime.  The only other thing will be a second opinion or referral to a hematologist.  Your onc must have a good reason to make this decision due to the location of the clot - in the chest wall.  I agree with what he has said about the presence of a clot and long term implications.  Be careful, we are part of a support group and have no access to your medical records and our advice are based on your input.  The best advice we can give you is for a second opinion; in absence of this listen to your doctors and ask ask ask lots of questions after doing some research. As I said before, holding on chemo may be not a bad thing if is done to save your life.  Think about this.

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 11:09AM activern wrote: I came across this story for the first time and surprisingly I was not shocked.  My first feeling was a misdiagnosis but the more I read the more I felt that BC at 10 is not impossible.  I have young ones in my family who start menstruating at 10/11 and right now my niece who is only 8 is starting to show signs of puberty.  So starting puberty this early shows that hormonal activity can begin at young ages ie. risks of breast cancer - unfortunately. Scientists are probably doing studies on this but I have not done any searches to find out - anyone? My prayers to Hannah and her family.
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 05:45PM activern wrote: I agree so wholeheartedly that the scans should be done like cancer.  Cancer has its own mind and can move quickly or slowly depending on where it is located - however; once it is stage 4 and receptor sites are positive - it tends to be a little more aggressive.  Push for your scans to be done sooner - damn those oncologists - they have a mind of their own and are so not consistent.  Tell him what you want girl!  Once I learned that my cancer returned, I was like a bitch on a racehorse - I pushed everybody around to get what I needed........   My prayers are with you - Love.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 03:01AM activern wrote: Hello all:  I have recurrence with IBC Stage IV with liver mets.  4 large areas on my right lobe.  Thing is it was found early so none of my labs tests are abnormal and no abdominal pain/tenderness.  I am have just received my second dose of A/C, her2 positive and plan for Herceptin when my AC is cycle and CT scan completed.  I am so happy to hear that liver mets is treatable - I was scared to S#@%!  Is anyone in this group on SS Disability - are you this ill?  Should I start my app - I am an RN and unable to work as hard as I did due to tiredness, but can still work full time.  What do you all think?

Personally: I had [have] big time depression and have been taking Effexor XR 225 daily and helped a great deal. However, since I have been on disability and away from work, the need for the drug has decreased (YAY!!) so I have been weaning from it.  I have been using Benadryl to sleep and take OTC like 369 and Vit B.  Other than that, only nasty chemo and drugs to go with it before I infuse! Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Want to hear from Stg IV BC re: Plan of Care activern activern

Posts.Content: activern wrote: I know many posts have been written but I want to hear from some of my breast friends regarding their plan of care as decided by your medical and surgical team.  Quick history:  recurrence of breast cancer after 12 years of follow-up mammos etc from Stage 1 DCIS; now IBC with Stage IV Liver Mets diagnosed June of this year.  Had scans etc; chemo A/C started in July and recently discovered that my HER2 is negative so my onc basically told me that his plan is to continue A/C with follow-up scans to determine progress - I had one of those scans today.  I also met with my Oncology surgeon who now states that a mastectomy is more palliative and if I "choose" even if my liver becomes clean.  He however, refuses to do a bilateral mastectomy saying that the risk is too high and forget reconstruction since in all of his years of practice he has never seen reconstruction done on a Stage IV patient.  So I will be walking around basically 1/2 chested.  What do you all think and what is your experience. Vilma Gordon Dx 5/1997, DCIS, Left, 1cm, Stage 0, 0/19 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 6/10/1997 Lumpectomy: Left; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Saline implant; Reconstruction (right): Saline implant Radiation Therapy 10/1/1997 Breast Hormonal Therapy 1/6/2009 Dx 6/24/2009, IBC, Left, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 9/15/2009 AC Surgery 3/10/2010 Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 10/18/2013 Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Surgery 7/24/2014 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Want to hear from Stg IV BC re: Plan of Care activern activern

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2014 06:08AM activern wrote: Me and radiation therapy:  first let me say how happy I am to found this thread !!   I first had 4 weeks of RT in 1997 when I was first diagnosed with BC.  I had a bout of anemia and took a week off until my numbers went up. I had my second experience with bone mets this winter>   The RO recommended Steriotactic RT and this was an experience.  The radiation is directly focused on the site - something like gamma knife and given in higher doses in a lower period of time.  I had 3 doses with each session lasting for an hour.  I ended up in the ER the first time with vomiting dark blood.  the second time was event free and the third time vomiting again but knew what was coming so gulped my Zofran after vomiting twice..  not me again.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 10:46PM activern wrote: Dear Heidi and family:  What I think is so unique about this post including all the massive responses is the updates we get from you guys.  Thank you Lil Bro and wife:  your description of Heidi's 'progress' is amazing.  I use the word 'progress' since her days of suffering appears to be coming to an end and while this may be difficult for your family to witness, she will be at peace and I call that progress.  My younger sister passed last Fall from Breast Cancer and we had the same experiences - she actually breathed her last in my arms and we felt relief after her passing.  I travelled to be with her on several occasions in the last two years and I again rushed to see her on her last day because she kept asking for me.  She barely lasted a few hours after I arrived.  Suffering is the worst part of this journey... Sad but true.  I will continue to pray for her and all of you - this too shall pass.  All my Love.
